questions.text: Pederson's hypothesis explains which of the following complications of GDM?
questions.solution:
• Macrosomia is defined as fetal weight more than 90th centile for that gestational age or estimated fetal weight equal to or more than 4000g.
  • This effect is seen after 20 weeks of gestation when the fetal pancreatic islet cells are capable of secreting insulin in response to hyperglycemia.
  • It is suggested that intrinsic fetal pancreatic beta cell hyperplasia assists in maternal glycemic control.
  • Insulin acts like a growth factor & causes excessive fetal growth and deposition of subcutaneous fat in the baby.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Pederson's hypothesis.

questions.text: Women with pregestational diabetes who are planning a pregnancy should try & aim to keep their HbA1c level below:
questions.solution:
• Women with diabetes who are planning a pregnancy should try & aim to keep their HbA1c level below 6.5%.
  • This is the recommended target for women with pregestational diabetes who are planning a pregnancy.
  • Achieving this level helps reduce the risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus, including congenital anomalies

KEY TAKEAWAY -

Reference: NICE guidelines on Diabetes in Pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following congenital anomalies is more commonly seen in 2nd half of gestation in a woman with pregestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
• Though most congenital anomalies occur early in gestation, a condition called the small left colon syndrome may be seen in second half of gestation especially in type 1 diabetes.
  • In this, there is uniformly small diameter of the descending and sigmoid colon and the rectum.
  • It may result from wide fluctuations in the maternal and fetal glycemic levels.
  • A neonate with small left colon syndrome may present with intestinal obstruction and may mimic meconium plug syndrome.

Optionwise explanations:

a. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect): While congenital heart defects like VSD can occur in infants of mothers with diabetes, they are not specifically more common in the second half of gestation.

b. Sacral agenesis: This anomaly is associated with maternal diabetes, particularly in the first trimester, and is a part of the caudal regression syndrome. It is not primarily associated with the second half of gestation.

d. Meningomyelocele: This neural tube defect is more associated with maternal folic acid deficiency and can occur at various stages of gestation. It is not specifically noted for being more common in the second half.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Small left colon syndrome, as it is a congenital anomaly more frequently seen in the second half of gestation in women with pregestational diabetes mellitus.It is characterized by a narrow left colon and can lead to complications such as intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 32 year old primigravida was diagnosed with GDM at 24 weeks of gestation. She was non-compliant to MNT & oral hypoglycemic therapy. She delivered a male baby at 38 weeks of gestation. All of the following neonatal complications can be seen, except:
questions.solution:
Hypermagnesemia: This is not typically associated with infants of mothers with GDM. In fact, magnesium levels are usually normal or low in these infants, and hypermagnesemia is more commonly related to maternal magnesium supplementation or other medical conditions.

Optionwise explanation:

A. hypoglycemia occurs due to hyperinsulinemia in the fetus and removal of the exogenous glucose source (maternal) at the time of delivery. Hence these babies be closely observed.

B. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcaemia occurs due to delayed postnatal parathyroid hormone regulation, pathophysiology of which is still unclear.

D. hyperbilirubinemia in GDM is increased due to preterm delivery, ineffective erythropoiesis, expanded red cell mass and relative immaturity of the hepatic bilirubin conjugation and excretion.

Key TAKEAWAY- The cause of hypomagnesaemia is similar to that of calcium metabolism in the neonate. It could also occur due to long standing diabetic nephropathy in the mother leading to maternal renal magnesium losses and hence reduced availability of magnesium for the fetus.

questions.text: All of the following organs are affected in a macrosomic fetus of a diabetic mother, except:
questions.solution:
• Maternal hyperglycaemia prompts fetal hyperinsulinemia, particularly during the second half of gestation. This in turn stimulates excessive somatic growth or macrosomia.
  • Except for the brain, most fetal organs are affected by the macrosomia that characterizes the fetus of a diabetic woman.

Optionwise explanation:

  1. Liver: The liver is often enlarged in macrosomic infants due to increased glycogen storage and fat accumulation, making it one of the organs affected by maternal diabetes.
  2. Heart: Cardiac hypertrophy can occur in macrosomic infants due to increased demand on the heart from excessive fetal growth and insulin exposure, making the heart another affected organ.
  3. Pancreas: The pancreas typically undergoes hyperplasia in response to high levels of maternal glucose, resulting in increased insulin production to handle the elevated blood sugar levels. This can lead to an enlarged pancreas in the fetus.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Although the brain may grow normally, it is typically not classified as an organ that undergoes significant pathological changes due to maternal diabetes in the context of macrosomia. Instead, the brain usually develops proportionately and does not show the same level of hypertrophy or abnormal growth as seen in other organs.

questions.text: Infants of diabetic mothers have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy that primarily affects which part of the heart?
questions.solution:
Infants of diabetic pregnancies may have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy that primarily affects the interventricular septum.

In severe cases, this cardiomyopathy may lead to obstructive cardiac failure.

Optionwise explanation:

B. Left auricle: While the left auricle may be affected in some heart conditions, it is not the primary site of hypertrophy in infants of diabetic mothers.

C. Interatrial septum - it is not commonly affected in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

D. Left ventricle: While the left ventricle may also show some hypertrophy, the interventricular septum is specifically noted for its significant thickening in this condition.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Interventricular septum, as this part of the heart is primarily affected in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy seen in infants of diabetic mothers.

questions.text: Best test to detect fetal lung maturity in a diabetic female:
questions.solution:
• Lung maturity is delayed in Diabetes Mellitus/Gestational Diabetes Mellitus.
  • L/S > 2:1 in amniotic fluid is not reliable to detect fetal lung maturity in diabetic mothers.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol in amniotic fluid is confirmatory of fetal lung maturity in these cases.

Optionwise explanation:

A. Lecithin: Sphingomyelin ratio: This test measures the ratio of lecithin (a phospholipid) to sphingomyelin in amniotic fluid. A ratio greater than 2:1 typically indicates fetal lung maturity. While this test is useful, it is not the most definitive indicator when considering other options.

B. Phosphatidylcholine: This is a component of surfactant, but it is not a standalone test for assessing fetal lung maturity. Its levels can contribute to the Lecithin: Sphingomyelin ratio.

D. Lamellar body count: This test measures the number of lamellar bodies in amniotic fluid, which are derived from type II pneumocytes and are indicative of surfactant production. Although it can provide information about lung maturity, it is less specific compared to phosphatidylglycerol.

KEY TAKEAWAY-Phosphatidylglycerol This is a phospholipid that is part of the surfactant system and appears later in the gestational period. Its presence in the amniotic fluid is a strong indicator of fetal lung maturity and suggests that the lungs are adequately developed. Therefore, this is the best test for detecting fetal lung maturity, especially in diabetic females, who may be at risk for complications.

questions.text: A G2P1L0D1 diabetic female present at 34 weeks' gestation with history of full term fetal demise in her previous pregnancy. Her glycaemic control is optimum and fetal status is reassuring. What is the most appropriate management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Because the patient has a significant risk factor for fetal demise due to her previous history. Inducing labor at 38 weeks allows for a safe delivery before the potential risks associated with post-term pregnancy and further complications can arise, particularly in a diabetic patient.

  • The risk of fetal death is three to four times higher in women with pregestational diabetes.
  • The most common time of IUD in a diabetic female is towards term.

Other option explanation:

B. Induction of labour at 40 weeks: While delivering at 40 weeks is generally considered safe for low-risk pregnancies, in this case, the history of full-term fetal demise raises concerns. Delaying induction until 40 weeks could increase the risk of another adverse outcome, especially considering her diabetes.

C. Elective Caesarean section at 38 weeks: Although a cesarean section can be indicated in certain cases, it is not necessary in this scenario unless there are specific obstetric indications (such as fetal distress or malpresentation). Since the fetal status is reassuring and her diabetes is well-controlled, induction of labor is a safer approach.

D. Wait for spontaneous labour: Given the previous history of fetal demise, waiting for spontaneous labor is not advisable. It increases the risk of recurrence of adverse outcomes, particularly in a diabetic patient.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Induction of labour at 38 weeks allows for a safe delivery before the potential risks associated with post-term pregnancy and further complications can arise, particularly in a diabetic patient like macrosomia and shoulder dystocia can occur.

choices.text: Fluid replacement is the sheet anchor of management
Insulin therapy is started as soon as possible
Hyperkalemia should be treated with potassium binding resin
Treatment of the underlying cause is important

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with pregestational diabetes presents at 36 weeks of gestation after multiple episodes of vomiting & diarrhoea. She is confused, disoriented, looks severely dehydrated with furred tongue & chapped lips. Lab investigations show Blood glucose 350 mg/dl, ketone bodies are present in urine sample. ABG sent. Report awaited. All of the following interventions are required to treat this condition, except:
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia should be treated with potassium binding resin: This statement is false. In DKA, hyperkalemia is common due to insulin deficiency and acidosis. However, the treatment typically involves administering insulin and fluids, which help drive potassium back into cells. Potassium-binding resins are not the first-line treatment for hyperkalemia in this context. Instead, the focus should be on monitoring potassium levels closely and administering intravenous fluids and insulin.

Option-wise explanation:

A. Fluid replacement is the sheet anchor of management: This statement is true. Fluid replacement is essential in the management of DKA to address dehydration and improve renal perfusion, allowing for better clearance of ketones and glucose.

B. Insulin therapy is started as soon as possible: This statement is true. Insulin therapy is crucial in the management of DKA as it helps to lower blood glucose levels and stop ketogenesis.

D. Treatment of the underlying cause is important: This statement is true. Identifying and addressing the underlying cause of DKA (such as infection, inadequate insulin therapy, or stressors) is critical for effective management.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Management of DKA.

  • More commonly seen in cases of type 1 diabetes, ketoacidosis can precipitate in conditions of excessive stress, diarrhoea, infection, preterm labour and others.
  • This is a life-threatening condition for the mother as well as the fetus.
  • Diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is made when:
  • Blood glucose >250mg/dl.
  • Ketone bodies in blood and urine
  • Arterial pH <7.3
  • Serum bicarbonate level <15meq/L
  • Fluid replacement: severe dehydration may result in a large fluid deficit as much as 6-7 litres. The estimated fluid deficit must be replaced in around 12-24 hours.
  • In the first hour, 1 litre of normal saline is infused, followed by 300-500ml/hr till pulse and BP are back to normal.
  • Hypokalemia generally occurs with DKA. KCl therapy can be given.
  • Insulin therapy is started as soon as possible.
  • Bicarbonate administration is required if pH falls less than 6.8.
  • Antibiotics are given.
  • Treatment of the cause is important.

questions.text: Cut off of HbA1c levels to strictly advise against pregnancy:
questions.solution:
• Women in the reproductive age group with diabetes should undergo a complete health checkup and preconceptional counselling prior to planning pregnancy to achieve optimal glycaemic control.
  • Therapy must be targeted to achieve a pre-pregnancy HbA1c of less than 6.1% (NICE guidelines).
  • This would likely reduce the risk of congenital anomalies.

Key TAKEAWAY- women with HbA1c >10% should be advised to avoid pregnancy.

Risk of congenital anomalies increased in such women.

questions.text: Following are the triggers for considering insulin therapy in pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
• Historically, insulin has been considered standard therapy in women with gestational diabetes when target glucose levels cannot be consistently achieved through nutrition and exercise.
  • Insulin does not cross the placenta, and tight glycemic control can usually be achieved.
  • Insulin therapy is typically added if fasting levels persist above 95 mg/dL in women with gestational diabetes.
  • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists also recommends that insulin be considered in women with 1-hour postprandial levels that persistently exceed 140 mg/dL or those with 2-hour levels >120 mg/dL.
  • While an HbA1c greater than 6.4% indicates poor long-term glycemic control and is a concern, it is not an immediate trigger for insulin therapy in the context of pregnancy. In pregnancy, the focus is typically on real-time blood glucose levels rather than HbA1c for managing insulin therapy.

KEY TAKEAWAY - self monitored capillary glucose level goals.

choices.text: It is a single step procedure
75g anhydrous glucose in 250-300ml of water is given and plasma glucose is estimated after 2 hours
A 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 140 mg/dl is considered as GDM

questions.text: Find the incorrect statement regarding DIPSI screening for GDM:
questions.solution:
Fasting is required: This statement is false. One of the key features of the DIPSI screening is that it does not require fasting before the glucose load. Women can consume food prior to the test.

Option-wise explanation:

A. It is a single-step procedure: This statement is true. DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) recommends a single-step procedure for screening for GDM, which simplifies the diagnostic process compared to multi-step approaches.

C. 75g anhydrous glucose in 250-300 ml of water is given and plasma glucose is estimated after 2 hours: This statement is true. The DIPSI protocol involves administering 75 grams of glucose dissolved in 250-300 ml of water, followed by plasma glucose measurement after 2 hours.

D. A 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 140 mg/dL is considered as GDM: This statement is true. According to the DIPSI criteria, a 2-hour plasma glucose level of 140 mg/dL or more indicates the presence of GDM.

KEY TAKEAWAY- DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Societies of India) recommends 1-step procedure with 75 gm oral anhydrous glucose in 250-300 ml of water without regard to the time of the last meal. A venous plasma glucose value at 2-hour more than 140 mg/dl is diagnosed as GDM.If blood sugar >200mg/dl it indicates overt diabetes.

choices.text: The first testing should be done during first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy
The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative
There should be at least 4 weeks gap between the two tests
The testing is not performed if the woman comes late in pregnancy for her first antenatal care after 28 weeks' time

questions.text: According to Indian guidelines for diagnosis of GDM, which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution:
Protocol for investigation

  • Testing for GDM is recommended twice during ANC.
  • The first testing should be done during first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy.
  • The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative. It is important to ensure second test as many pregnant women develop blood sugar intolerance during this period (24-28 weeks). Moreover, only one third of GDM positive women are detected during first trimester. If it could not be done during this time, then it can be done any time after 24 weeks of pregnancy.
  • There should be at least 4 weeks gap between the two tests.
  • The test is to be conducted for all pregnant women even if she comes late in pregnancy for ANC at the time of first contact.
  • If she presents beyond 28 weeks of pregnancy, only one test is to be done at the first point of contact.

Option-wise explanation:

  1. The first testing should be done during the first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy: This statement is true. Indian guidelines recommend that screening for diabetes should be performed as early as possible during the first antenatal visit.
  2. The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative: This statement is true. If the initial screening test for diabetes is negative, a second test is recommended between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation.
  3. There should be at least 4 weeks gap between the two tests: This statement is true. The guidelines suggest that there should be an adequate interval (at least 4 weeks) between the first and second screenings to ensure accurate results.

KEY TAKEAWAY- According to Indian guidelines, testing for GDM can still be performed even if the woman presents late in pregnancy (after 28 weeks). The rationale is that undiagnosed GDM can still pose risks to both the mother and fetus, and it is important to identify and manage it as early as possible, regardless of the gestational age.

Reference: Diagnosis & Management of Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (Technical and Operational Guidelines), Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, GOI

questions.text: Most common type of anemia seen in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Physiological anemia of pregnancy is the most common variant of anemia seen in pregnancy.
  • During pregnancy plasma volume expands (maximum around 32 weeks) resulting in hemoglobin dilution.
  • Maternal plasma volume increases by about 40-50%. RBC volume increases by 20%.
  • There is relative fall in the level of hemoglobin and hematocrit during pregnancy.
  • All these values return to normal by 6 weeks postpartum.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Dimorphic anemia

  • Dimorphic anemia refers to a condition where two different types of anemia coexist, typically iron deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. It is not the most common type seen in pregnancy.

b) Iron deficiency anemia

  • Iron deficiency anemia is indeed common in pregnancy due to increased iron demand for fetal development and increased blood volume. However, it is not considered the most prevalent type of anemia specifically during pregnancy.

d) Megaloblastic anemia

  • Megaloblastic anemia is caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. While it can occur during pregnancy, it is less common compared to physiological anemia and iron deficiency anemia.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Physiological anemia of pregnancy is characterized by an increase in plasma volume greater than the increase in red blood cell mass, leading to a dilutional effect. This condition results in lower hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
  • It is considered a normal adaptation in pregnancy.

questions.text: All of the following findings can be met with in a case of megaloblastic anemia, except:
questions.solution:
LD bodies

The oval nucleated amastigotes within the bone marrow, liver, spleen or lymph node cells are known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodies, seen in cases of Kala Azar.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Hypersegmented neutrophils

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are a classic finding in megaloblastic anemia. They are neutrophils with more than five nuclear lobes and indicate impaired DNA synthesis due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

b) Howell-Jolly bodies

  • Howell-Jolly bodies are small remnants of nuclear material found in red blood cells and are typically seen in cases of splenic dysfunction or asplenia. They can occur in megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis and splenic dysfunction.

d) Macrocytosis and anisocytosis

  • Macrocytosis (enlarged red blood cells) and anisocytosis (variation in red blood cell size) are hallmark features of megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Hematological examination in MEGALOBLASTIC ANEMIA

(1) Hemoglobin level is usually below 10 gm%

(2) Stained blood film: Presence of any two of the following features in the peripheral blood, but more often seen in buffy coat preparations, are diagnostic:

(a) Hypersegmentation of the neutrophils (5 or more lobes)

(b) macrocytosis and anisocytosis

(c) giant polymorphs

(d) megaloblasts

(e) Howell-Jolly bodies

(3) MCV is more than 100 µ3. MCH is high (more than 33 pg), but MCHC is normal

(4) Red cell folate is below 3 ng/ml

(5) Serum vitamin B12 level is below 90 pg/ml (normal levels 300 pg/ml)

(6) Bone marrow-shows megaloblastic erythropoiesis.

questions.text: A multigravida presents at 33 weeks of gestation with a history of fever. Identify the peripheral smear finding shown below:
questions.solution:
Gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum are crescent- or sausage-shaped, and are usually about 1.5 times the diameter of an RBC in length. Their identification in a peripheral smear confirms the diagnosis of P. falciparum induced malarial febrile illness in this woman.

Optionwise explanation:

Here's a brief overview of the other options for clarity:

a) Cabot rings

Cabot rings are thread-like structures that can be seen in red blood cells but are not sickle-shaped. They are associated with megaloblastic anemia and some other conditions.

b) Schistocytes

Schistocytes are fragmented red blood cells typically seen in conditions such as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). They do not appear sickle-shaped.

c) LD bodies: LD or Leishmania donovani bodies, are oval-shaped amastigotes that are found in the cytoplasm of cells in the reticulo-endothelial system, such as the bone marrow, liver, spleen, or lymph nodes. They are caused by the protozoan Leishmania donovani, which is transmitted by the bite of sandflies.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum - crescent- or sausage-shaped
  • Cabot ring- Megaloblastic anemia
  • LD bodies- Kala Azar
  • Schistocytes- DIC

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 54b The Diagnosis and Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 22 year old multigravida G3P2L2 presents to Antenatal OPD with complaints of easy fatigability, weakness & occasional dizziness at 24 weeks of gestation. On examination, pallor 2+, Pulse 104 bpm, BP 124/70 mmHg, RR 18 breaths/min. CBC shows Hb 8.6 gm/Dl, TLC 15000/cumm, platelet count 1.6 lac/cumm. Her nutritional status seems poor. To diagnose iron deficiency anemia, all of the following lab findings corroborate, except:
questions.solution:
Decreased TIBC is not typically seen in iron deficiency anemia. In fact, TIBC is often increased in iron deficiency anemia because the body increases transferrin production in response to low iron stores. other options:

b) Decreased serum ferritin

  • Decreased serum ferritin is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia. Ferritin is a measure of the body's iron stores, and low levels indicate depleted iron reserves.

c) Decreased transferrin saturation

  • Decreased transferrin saturation occurs in iron deficiency anemia because there is less iron available for binding to transferrin. This is a typical finding in the condition.

d) Decreased serum iron

  • Decreased serum iron is also characteristic of iron deficiency anemia. With insufficient iron available, serum iron levels fall.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

'Tips & Tricks'

All parameters of iron metabolism decrease during pregnancy except for the two 'T's:

Total iron binding capacity and Transferrin levels, which increase.

High TIBC means that you have low levels of iron. When there isn't much iron to attach to, you'll have a lot of free transferrin in your blood too.

choices.text: Substitution of valine for glutamine in position 6 in the beta-globin chains of the haemoglobin molecule results in the production of sickle cell haemoglobin
Reduced oxygen environments caused by hypoxia, cold, acidosis and dehydration precipitate sickling crisis
There is an increased risk of venous thromboembolism, pre-eclampsia & placental abruption
Women with SCD should be given high-dose folic acid (5 mg) and penicillin prophylaxis

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding sickle cell disease in pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
Substitution of valine by glutamine at position 6 in the beta-globin chains of the haemoglobin molecule results in the production of sickle cell haemoglobin

Explanation:  This statement is incorrect. The mutation that causes sickle cell disease involves the substitution of valine for glutamate/glutamic acid (not glutamine)at position 6 of the beta-globin chain of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of hemoglobin S (HbS). This is the correct answer, as it contains inaccurate information.

b) Reduced oxygen environments caused by hypoxia, cold, acidosis, and dehydration precipitate sickling crisis

  • Various factors, including low oxygen levels, cold temperatures, acidosis, and dehydration, can trigger sickling of red blood cells, leading to painful crises.

c) There is an increased risk of venous thromboembolism, pre-eclampsia, and placental abruption

  • Women with sickle cell disease have higher risks of these complications during pregnancy, necessitating close monitoring and management.

d) Women with SCD should be given high-dose folic acid (5 mg) and penicillin prophylaxis

  • Folic acid supplementation is essential to help with increased red blood cell production, and penicillin prophylaxis is recommended to prevent infections due to functional asplenia in SCD patients.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

choices.text: Daily excretion through gut, urine & sweat - 200 mg

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched with respect to iron requirement in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
This statement is incorrectly matched. The total iron requirement for the fetus and placenta is typically around 300 mg, not 500 mg. This value accounts for the iron needed for fetal development and placental growth.

b) RBC mass - 500 mg

During pregnancy, the increase in red blood cell mass requires approximately 500 mg of iron to support the expanded blood volume and maintain oxygen delivery.

c) Daily excretion through gut, urine & sweat - 200 mg

. The total iron loss through gastrointestinal (GI) excretion, urine, and sweat during pregnancy is estimated at about 200 mg.

d) Blood loss at delivery - 200 mg

The average blood loss during delivery is typically around 200-400 mg of iron, depending on the delivery method and individual circumstances.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

questions.text: A 24 year old multigravida with mild iron deficiency anemia in the 2nd trimester is started on oral iron therapy. Which of the following parameters is the first to rise suggesting an improvement during treatment?
questions.solution:
• The increase in haemoglobin with oral iron is about 0.8 g/dl per week and this is reflected in a significant elevation of the haemoglobin/haematocrit concentration when repeated 2 weeks after initiation of treatment.
  • Mild to moderate iron-deficiency anemia responds to adequate iron therapy, and the first hematological response is an elevated reticulocyte count.

Optionwise explanation:

a) MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin)

  • This parameter reflects the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell. While it may improve over time with effective treatment, it is not the first indicator of improvement.

b) MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume)

  • MCV indicates the average volume of red blood cells. Similar to MCH, it may increase as the anemia improves, but it is not the first parameter to change.

c) Hb level (Hemoglobin level)

  • Hemoglobin levels are crucial for assessing anemia. However, while they will increase with successful treatment, this typically takes longer to manifest compared to other.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

. The reticulocyte count is an early indicator of bone marrow response to anemia and iron therapy. After starting iron supplementation, the bone marrow responds by increasing the production of reticulocytes, which are immature red blood cells. Therefore, reticulocyte count is usually the first parameter to rise, indicating an improvement in the patient's condition.

questions.text: Which of the following hematological criteria remains unchanged in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
MCHC : MCHC parameter remains relatively unchanged in pregnancy. It reflects the concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells and does not fluctuate significantly during pregnancy despite the hemodilution that occurs.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Blood volume

  • Blood volume increases significantly during pregnancy to support the growing fetus and placenta, typically expanding by about 40-50%.

b) TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity)

  • TIBC usually increases during pregnancy due to the increased production of transferrin in response to higher iron requirements.

d) S. ferritin (Serum ferritin)

  • Serum ferritin levels often decrease during pregnancy due to increased iron utilization for fetal development and changes in maternal iron stores.

Key TAKEAWAY-

MCV increases slightly but MCHC remains unchanged in pregnancy.

Blood volume increases by 40-50 %

TIBC increases

S.ferritin decreases.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with a rise in MCV, except:
questions.solution:
Thalassemia typically presents with microcytic anemia, where red blood cells are smaller than normal, leading to a decreased MCV.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism is associated with macrocytic anaemia, leading to an increase in MCV due to impaired DNA synthesis affecting red blood cell maturation.

b) Vitamin B12 deficiency

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia, which results in larger than normal red blood cells (macrocytes), thereby increasing MCV.

c) Alcoholism

  • Alcoholism can lead to macrocytic anaemia due to its effects on folate metabolism and direct toxic effects on the bone marrow, resulting in an increased MCV.

KEY TAKEAWAY - DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS OF MICROCYTIC ANEMIA

IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA

SIDEROBLASTIC ANEMIA

THALASEMIA

ANAEMIA OF CHRONIC DISEASES.

choices.text: Iron chelation therapy should be stopped and folate supplementation should be given
Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy
The aim during pregnancy is to maintain the haemoglobin level above 7 g/dL

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding management of beta thalassemia in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
The aim during pregnancy is to avoid fluctuations in the haemoglobin concentration and the cardiac workload and this means to maintain the haemoglobin level above 10 g/dL. Hence transfusions are likely to be required at a 3-weekly interval.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Parenteral iron should be avoided

  • Correct. Parenteral iron is typically avoided in beta-thalassemia unless there is documented iron deficiency because iron overload can be a problem in thalassemia patients, especially those requiring frequent transfusions.

b) Iron chelation therapy should be stopped and folate supplementation should be given

  • Correct. Iron chelation therapy, such as with deferoxamine, is usually stopped during pregnancy due to potential teratogenic effects, and folate supplementation is important for both maternal and fetal health.

c) Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy

  • Correct. Pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for patients with thalassemia, particularly those with functional asplenia or those who have undergone splenectomy.

Key TAKEAWAY- The target hemoglobin level during pregnancy is generally higher, around 10 g/dL, to ensure adequate oxygenation for both mother and fetus.
